datafield.subfield: Hans Christian Ørsted, narratives, oeuvres and physics education

In 1820 the Danish scientist Hans Christian Ørsted discovered the relationship between electricity and magnetism by his famous wire-compass experiment. Ørsted was one of the foremost scientists of the nineteenth century, and he was also one of the leading figures in Denmark in the 19th century with a vital influence in the fields of aesthetics, philosophy, education, politics and religion. In this paper the work and life of Ørsted is placed in a school context with the rationale to accentuate that learning of physics needs to be accompanied by learning about physics, its history, its interrelations with culture, worldviews, and commerce, its philosophical assumptions, its epistemology and methodology. Narratives are introduced as a pedagogical support to this approach and two concrete examples of teaching sequences centred on the work and life of Ørsted is described in grade 7 and grade 9 classes, respectively. A prominent feature of the sequences was that all the activities of the pupils as an outcome should have a product. Products like a movie, a loudspeaker, a fairy tale or a newspaper played an important role by encouraging the pupils to produce both personally meaningful works as well as products that are useful for their community.

The British bombardment of Copenhagen in 1807. Ørsted lived in Copenhagen during the bombardment, and wrote a letter about the fires in the city and the destroyed buildings including the spire of the Church of Our Lady to his friend Adam Oehlenschläger, the leading figure of Danish Romanticism and the poet of Denmark's national anthem

'The Airship' a poem by Ørsted, where he combines artistic and scientific ideals in and 'The drop of water' a poem by Hans Christian Andersen about an old man, called Krible-Krable, is looking at a drop of water from the ditch with a magnifying glass and observing the many small animals are bouncing and jumping. It is said that Andersen found inspiration to the poem by a visit to a botanist, who showed him in his microscopes, and by a microscope demonstrated by his friend Ørsted

The magnetic field of the Earth. After his discovery of electromagnetism Ørsted turned his attention the magnetism and participated in the world-wide observations of the Earth's magnetic field organized by Gauss and Weber. InDenmark's first satellite named after Ørsted was launched with the objective to map the Earth's magnetic field and collect data to determine the changes occurring in the field
